Subject: Re: [neat] Does Novelty Search Learn Exploratory Skills?
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=464818732; y=Oa8_Xf70vSeUQPDFChZA_WqYT0-6yy46YsM4rqGB-90XejrHjx5r

Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset=windows-1252

Hi Ken, 

Please see below.

> Hi Jeff, regarding the evolvability of novel=
ty vs. fitness, it may be more interesting than I previously realized to co=
nsider your new paper with Roby in conjunction with our 2011 paper on evolv=
ability with novelty search:
> http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/papers/lehman_cec11.=
pdf
> 
> These papers are complementary in the sense that they actually bot=
h look at novelty search and fitness in the hard maze.  Our 2011 paper look=
s at evolvability, which is measured as distinct behaviors that can be gene=
rated from a candidate genome.  More evolvable genomes generate more distin=
ct behaviors.  Your paper looks at measures that are related (area covered,=
 distance traveled), though not identical.
> 
> Interestingly, our old resu=
lts and your results (both in the hard maze) looks somewhat consistent.  Th=
at is, if you look at the evolvability comparison between solutions in NS a=
nd fitness in the hard maze in figure 4a in our paper, you see that actuall=
y the difference, though we found it significant, is not very big (26.03 vs=
. 24.76).   That might be genuinely consistent even with the small differen=
ce (if any) you see between novelty "prior to further evolution," e.g. in f=
igure 5 in your paper, which shows 4.16% explored for novelty vs. 4.04% for=
 fitness.  I think that consistency is actually a nice hint that our setups=
 are compatible.
> 
> But here's the interesting part: It turns out that wh=
ere Joel and I saw dramatic gaps was the evolvability for the whole populat=
ion, which is something you were not looking at, because you were looking o=
nly at solutions (as in our figure 4a). If you look at figure 4b in our pap=
er, which examines whole populations, you can see that the evolvability of =
the most evolvable member of the NS population is way higher than for fitne=
ss (about 35 vs 25).  In addition, even the average evolvability is a lot h=
igher (about 20 for NS vs.15 for fitness).   
> 
That is an interesting obs=
ervation. My guess is that it stems from the fact that novelty search has g=
reater diversity in its population, such that you'd expect higher variance =
with respect to most traits, evolvability included. But that does not dimin=
ish the point that you make: novelty search search populations are probably=
 much better positioned to adapt to an environmental change than a populati=
on evolved with traditional, objective-based search.

> 
> This observation=
 suggests that, if you think of NS as a method for gathering interesting be=
haviors (and not for solving one particular problem), then what you are get=
ting in aggregate is a lot of behaviors that are better for generating furt=
her interesting behaviors.  The fitness-based populations lack this propert=
y, even if the evolvability of a particular type of behavior is not dramati=
cally different between the two.
> 
> However, that still does not explain =
why even a particular solution from NS should not be a lot more evolvable t=
han from fitness.  I still think it should be in principle, but perhaps the=
 hard maze is not the right domain to tease that out.  Perhaps the issue in=
 the hard maze is that actually none of the behaviors (as measured by last =
point visited) actually require a great deal of complexity, so you don't se=
e the accumulated nasty effect of "bad complexity" growing on top of bad co=
mplexity that fitness is expected to produce.   That is, the solution to th=
e hard maze is not yet complex enough that the additional awkward structure=
 added in the fitness searches exacts that much of a toll on evolvability f=
or the particular solution.  But I bet that if you found really radically c=
omplex behaviors with NS (yet to be shown) that if fitness ever could even =
reach such a behavior, its representation would be horrible and its evolvab=
ility therefore much lower.
> 
> Of course, this kind of comparison (on ide=
ntically-performaing highly complex solutions) could prove impossible to ma=
ke because ultimately really complex behaviors may not be possible to disco=
ver through fitness anyway, so you'd never be able to see the example of th=
e corrupted complexity in the fitness case.  
> 
I agree that it is a fasci=
nating question why the novelty search organisms are not more evolvable. I =
also agree that the hard maze may be too simple a task to get at the answer=
. I think there's a lot more exciting research to be done into this questio=
n, and I look forward to seeing it unfold in the coming years.
	
> 
> Best,=

> 
> ken
> 
> 


--Apple-Mail=_86D3902E-27BA-4AFA-BBDD-FDC45732395B
